Issues.Title: Improve linkability for WPF
Issues.Body:
At the top-level, WPF apps should be able to use trimming with predictable results.

## Goals

- [ ] WPF template produces zero/minimal trim warnings
- [ ] WPF APIs which are not linker-friendly are correctly annotated

## Progress

### Information gathering

- [ ] Generate list of warnings produced when linking a representative WPF app
- [ ] Categorize warnings, sorting to netcore warnings and WPF-specific warnings (see https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/43078)
- [ ] Identify the cause of the warnings and propose fixes

### Code fixes

- [ ] Fix warnings or annotate APIs as necessary
- [ ] Identify linker-unsafe constructs and propose replacements for functionality
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Improve linkability for WPF" (#3811)

Issues.Title: Binding should respond when any property changes?
Issues.Body:
Trying to understand how to achieve a binding (with a converter) to update whenever any property on a `DataContext` object changes.

Example,
```xaml
<Button DataContext="some complex object that implements INotifyPropertyChanged">
   <TextBlock Text={Binding Converter=...} />
</Button>
```
The complex type accurately sends `PropertyChanged` events, but since the inner Binding does not specify a Path, no updates are triggered.

Is this expected behavior?
Is there a better/proper way of achieving this?

(We have tried triggering a PropertyChanged event for `string.Empty`/`null`, but that only works for update Bindings that are bound a specific property of a complex object)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Binding should respond when any property changes?" (#3810)

Issues.Title: References referred in WPF XAML only not copied to main project output
Issues.Body:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity2.visualstudio.com/t/References-referred-in-WPF-XAML-only-not/850184)._ --- I noted that references which is used only in the XAML files are not copied to the main project output. Example of dependency layout. 1) `Project_WPF_Converters` - Contains only converters 2) `Project_WPF_Pages` - Includes `Project_WPF_Converters` - References to (1) are all inside the .xaml files via `xmlns:c="clr-namespace:My.Converters;assembly=My.Converters"` 3) `Project_Main` - Includes `Project_WPF_Pages` After build, - in `Project_WPF_Pages` output folder, `Project_WPF_Converters.dll` is copied. - in `Project_Main` output folder, only `Project_WPF_Pages.dll` is copied. `Project_WPF_Converters.dll` is not. --- ### Original Comments #### Feedback Bot on 12/10/2019, 03:01 PM:

We have directed your feedback to the appropriate engineering team for further evaluation. The team will review the feedback and notify you about the next steps.

#### Feedback Bot on 1/17/2020, 07:15 AM: I have detected that for the last 35 days, this issue didn't have much product team activity and a very small amount of new votes or comments. Based on this, its severity, and affected area, it’s my experience that this issue is very unlikely to be fixed. #### Mila Zhou[MSFT] on 10/13/2020, 02:11 PM:

Thank you for taking the time to log this issue! Did you still reproduce this issue in the latest stable version of Visual Studio installed from https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/downloads ?

#### Nicholas Poh on 10/13/2020, 02:52 PM: (private comment, text removed) --- ### Original Solutions (no solutions)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "References referred in WPF XAML only not copied to main project output" (#3802)

Issues.Title: Build of the WPF Custom Control Library is failed in .net 5 if "µ" character used in path and project
Issues.Body:
.NET Version: 5.0.100, released 10th Nov 2020 / Windows 10 ver 2004 (Build 19041.572), German.

Just migrated one of my pet project from Core 3.1 to 5.0 and got weird and funny problem.
If you have "µ" character in the name of the path and have WPF Custom Control Library, then attempt to build from command line (with "dotnet build" command) failed with error MC3050.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Create a folder with "µ" character, for example, "µmControl"
2. From this folder execute the command: dotnet new wpfcustomcontrollib
3. Try to build just created project from command line: dotnet build

Result: "\Generic.xaml(5,12): error MC3050: Der Typ "local:CustomControl1"wurde nicht gefunden." (means "Type was not found").

I checked other "non-ascii" characters like üöä - everything works as expected, without any problem. Not sure which other chars except "µ" can cause this.
Also if I open "failed" project with "µ" char in Visual Studio (16.8.0), then I can build without problem as well. The only dotnet build command failed. Previosly in .net Core 3.1 is was OK, only 5.0 failed.
It doesn't matter if the WPF Custom Control with "µ" char created in Visual Studio or from command line. Build in VisualStudio successful, but from command line failed.

If you need additional info - please let me know.
With best regards,
Andrey.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Build of the WPF Custom Control Library is failed in .net 5 if "µ" character used in path and project" (#3801)

Issues.Title: Remove usage of Microsoft.NETCore.App.Internal package.
Issues.Body: The Microsoft.NETCore.App.Internal package is being removed in https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/38457/. The usage in WPF can be replaced with the .NET Core Shared Framework VS insertion package, which is a supported package to reference a runtime version.

Issues.Title: MenuItem with ApplicationCommand doesn't get localized in self-contained deployment
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 3.1.9/3.1.403
* Windows version: 1909 10.0.18363
* Does the bug reproduce also in WPF for .NET Framework 4.8?: N/A

 <!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->
 
 **Problem description:**
When you bind a command from `ApplicationCommands` such as `Save` to a `MenuItem`, it is supposed to display a localized label and key shortcut.
 
 **Actual behavior:** <!-- callstack for crashes / exceptions -->
On a machine with de-DE locale and a window with `Window.Language = "fr-FR"`:

If the program is published as framework-dependent or run from the build directory, the menu item is "Speichern Strg+S" (i.e in German).

If the program is published as self-contained, the menu item is "Save Ctrl+S". Note that `CultureInfo.CurrentCulture` and `CultureInfo.CurrentUICulture` both return de-DE. Date and number formatting also follow de-DE culture.
 
 **Expected behavior:**
In both cases the `MenuItem`should be localized to de-DE or fr-FR (not sure about the semantics of `Window.Language`).

 **Minimal repro:**
Start with "WPF App (.Net Core)" template.

MainWindow.xaml:
```XAML
<Window x:Class="ReproPublish.MainWindow"
        xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation"
        xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml"
        xmlns:d="http://schemas.microsoft.com/expression/blend/2008"
        xmlns:mc="http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/markup-compatibility/2006"
        mc:Ignorable="d"
        Title="MainWindow" Height="450" Width="800"
        Language="fr-FR">
    <Window.CommandBindings>
        <CommandBinding Command="ApplicationCommands.Save" Executed="CommandSave_Executed"/>
    </Window.CommandBindings>
    <Grid>
        <Grid.RowDefinitions>
            <RowDefinition Height="Auto"/>
            <RowDefinition/>
        </Grid.RowDefinitions>
        <Menu Grid.Row="0">
            <MenuItem Header="Test">
                <MenuItem Command="ApplicationCommands.Save"/>
            </MenuItem>
        </Menu>
    </Grid>
</Window>
```

MainWindow.xaml.cs (default except command handler with optional test output):
```C#
using System;
using System.Globalization;
using System.Windows;
using System.Windows.Input;

namespace ReproPublish
{
    public partial class MainWindow : Window
    {
        public MainWindow()
        {
            InitializeComponent();
        }

        private void CommandSave_Executed(object sender, ExecutedRoutedEventArgs e)
        {
            MessageBox.Show(this, $"CC: {CultureInfo.CurrentCulture.Name}\nCUIC: {CultureInfo.CurrentUICulture.Name}\nTime: {DateTime.Today}\nNumber: {1.5}");
        }
    }
}
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "MenuItem with ApplicationCommand doesn't get localized in self-contained deployment" (#3784)

Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "[master] Update dependencies from dotnet/winforms" (#3782)

Issues.Title: Runtime exception in .net Core 3.1 App when changing p:AssemblyVersion on build
Issues.Body:
I have a .net Core 3.1 WPF app. And I compile it with the command:

`dotnet publish -o "output" -c Release "Foo.sln" -p:AssemblyVersion="1.2.3.4"`

If I leave out the AssemblyVersion parameter all works fine. But with this parameter I get a runtime exception on startup.

"Could not register named object. Cannot register duplicate name 'MaxDetailsContentHeightHelper' in this scope."

It seems to be a line in the XAML
`<Border Visibility="Hidden" Grid.Row="0" x:Name="MaxDetailsContentHeightHelper"/>`

I have no idea where to look for or what could be the reason.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Runtime exception in .net Core 3.1 App when changing p:AssemblyVersion on build" (#3793)
